children.name: to reject an offer or suggestion
reject b2
children.definition: reject/rɪˈdʒekt/  to say no very firmly to an offer or suggestion. reject is more formal than not accept and say no:từ chối
examples: ▪ lauren rejected her parents’ offer of financial help.
lauren từ chối sự hổ trợ tài chính chủa cha mẹ mình
▪ she rejected the idea that she should sue him.
cô ấy từ chối ý kiến cho rằng anh ta nên kiện anh ta
▪ the secretary of state offered his resignation, which the president promptly rejected.
bộ trưởng ngoại giao hoa kì đề nghị ông ấy từ chức ,nhưng tổng thống đã từ chối
rejection/rɪˈdʒekʃən/ [uncountable noun]sự bác bỏ
▪ the government’s outright rejection of the proposals
sự bác bỏ hoàn toàn của chính phủ về những đề xuất

children.name: not accept b1
children.definition: not accept/nɒt əkˈsept/  to say no to an offer or invitation, especially because you think it would not be right to accept it:không chấp nhận
examples: ▪ she’s given us all this stuff and she won’t accept any money for it.
cô ấy đưa cho chúng tôi tất cả những thứ nay nhưng cô ấy không chấp nhận nhận tiền.
▪ i decided not to accept their invitation.
tôi quyết định không chấp nhận lời mời của họ
▪ laney wouldn’t accept what he considered an insulting pay offer.
lany sẽ không chấp nhận với những gì mà anh ta đề nghị bồi thường vì xúc phạm đến tôi.

children.name: say no a1
children.definition: say no  especially spoken not accept an offer or suggestion:nói không
examples: ▪ i asked him if he wanted a drink, but he said no.
▪ i’ll offer to buy it from her, but i expect she’ll say no.
say no to
▪ mrs. hill, still mentally alert, said no to any suggestions of further operations.

children.name: refuse b1
children.definition: refuse/rɪˈfjuːz/  to say you do not want something that you have been offered: từ chối
examples: ▪ the offer was so good how could i refuse?
cái đề nghị này quá tốt làm sao tôi có thể từ chối được?
▪ he never refuses a drink, does he?
anh ấy không từ chối uống nước không?
refuse to do something
từ chối làm cái gì
▪ ms. knight refused to accept the manager’s apology.
ông knight từ chối chấp nhận lời xin lỗi của giám đốc của mình
flatly refuse: từ chối thẳng thắng
▪ he flatly refuses any offers of financial help.
anh ấy từ chối thẳng thắng bất kì đề xuất giúp đỡ về tài chính

children.name: turn down b2
children.definition: turn down/ˌtɜːʳn ˈdaʊn/  to say no to an offer - use this especially when someone refuses a good offer or opportunity, and this is surprising:từ chối
examples: turn somebody/something down: từ chối ai đó/ cái gì dó
▪ they offered her a really good job, but she turned it down
▪ he said he’d help her with her training, but she turned him down.
turn down somebody/something từ chôi ai, cái gì
▪ if you turn down the opportunity to go to college, you’ll always regret it.

children.name: decline b2
children.definition: decline formal to say no politely when someone invites you to do something:khước từ
examples: ▪ mr casey regrets that he will have to decline your kind invitation owing to a prior engagement.
▪ the bishop was invited to attend the opening ceremony, but he declined.
decline to dosth
▪ the prime minister was asked for his opinion but declined to comment.

children.name: i’ll take a rain check x
children.definition: i’ll take a rain checkspoken use this to tellsbthat you cannot accept their invitation at the time they have suggested, but would like to do it at some time in the future: hẹn dịp khác
examples: ‘how about dinner tonight?’ ‘sorry -- i’ll have to take a rain check on that.’

children.name: to refuse to give sb a job, a place at college etc
reject b2
children.definition: reject to formally tell sb, usually in writing, that they have not got the job or chance to study that they have asked for:loại
examples: several hundred people applied, but we had to reject nearly all of them.
ian was rejected by the army because of his bad eyesight.
jim was rejected by every college he applied to.
rejection[c or u] c2
i got a rejection from harvard, but i’m still waiting to hear from ucla.

children.name: turn down b2
children.definition: turn down to tell someone that they cannot have the job or chance to study that they have asked for, especially when there is a particular reason for doing this:từ chối
examples: when uncle john tried to join the army, they turned him down because he was too old.
marion applied for a job teaching in minneapolis, but she was turned down.
we automatically turn down any candidate who makes spelling mistakes in their job application.

children.name: not accept b1
children.definition: not accept to not give sb the job or chance to study that they have asked for:không chấp nhận
examples: he applied for several jobs at the amusement park, but wasn’t accepted.
most universities will not accept anyone without an interview.

children.name: to reject sb who wants to be friendly or help you
reject b2
children.definition: reject/rɪˈdʒekt/  to refuse to speak or listen to someone who wants to be friendly with you or wants to help you:từ chối (sự giúp đỡ)
examples: ▪ samantha had consistently rejected all bob’s offers of help.
▪ she’s scared to try to talk to him about it in case he rejects her again.
▪ as a child he was repeatedly rejected by both parents.
rejection[uncountable noun]c2
▪ of course, you always risk rejection when you first ask someone out.

children.name: rebuff x
children.definition: rebuff to rejectsb’sfriendly invitation or offer in an unpleasant or rude way, so that they feel offended:cự tuyệt, khước từ
examples: she rebuffed all my attempts to make things up between us, till eventually my patience snapped.
despite being rebuffed again and again, he continued to phone her.

children.name: brush-off x
children.definition: give sb the brush-off  informal to refuse to acceptsb’shelp, friendship, invitations etc in a rude and unfriendly way:phớt lờ, gạt bỏ
examples: ▪ russell tried to give me the brush-off, but i don’t give up that easily.
▪ the new director of the urban league was given the brush-off by city hall.

children.name: snub x
children.definition: snub/snʌb/  to deliberately behave in an unfriendly way to someone, for example by ignoring them or being rude to them, so that they feel hurt:hất hủi, lạnh nhạt
examples: ▪ rosanna felt snubbed when she wasn’t invited to the wedding.
rosanna cảm thấy bị hất hủi khi cô không được mời đến tiệc cưới
▪ high-schoolers will often snub anyone they feel is different or strange.
các trường trung học thường hất hửi những người họ thấy khác biệt hay lạ lùng
▪ when the college invited him to speak, he was snubbed by students who felt his policies were unfair to minorities.
khi trường đại học mời ông ta lên phát biểu, ông cảm thấy bị lạnh nhạt bởi những học sinh mà nghĩ các chính sách của ông không công bằng với đa số mọi người
snub[c]:sựu hất hủi
▪ the assistant director took it as a snub when he was not invited to the conference.
trợ lí chỉ huy xem đó như là sự hất hủi khi anh ta không được mời đến buổi họp

children.name: ostracize x
children.definition: ostracize/ ostraciseuk if a group of people ostracize a person or another group, they refuse to talk to them and make them feel that they are strongly disliked:khai trừ, tẩy chay
examples: many young people are unwilling to admit that they are gay because they fear being ostracized.
he had committed crimes so appalling that even other prisoners ostracized him.

children.name: shun x
children.definition: shun to refuse to accept or be friendly with sb, especially because they are different from you in some way or have done sth that you disapprove of: xa lánh, tránh xa
examples: some young women are shunned by their families when they become pregnant outside of marriage.
recently bereaved widows often feel they are being shunned by people who don’t know what to say to them.
after the trial he was shunned by friends and family alike.

children.name: to change an order that sb has given
override x
children.definition: override/ˌəʊvəˈraɪd/  to use your power to change an order or decision that was made by someone with less power than you: thâu tóm, đè đầu cưỡi cổ
examples: ▪ congress has the power to override the president’s veto.
▪ churchill issued a new order overriding previous instructions.

children.name: overrule x
children.definition: overrule/ˌəʊvəˈruːl/  to use your power to change an order or decision, especially one made by a court of law or by a military leader, because you think it is wrong: bãi bỏ, bác bỏ
examples: ▪ after seeing new evidence the judge overruled the court’s original decision.
▪ a general commanding american troops on the battlefield found himself overruled by politicians back in washington.

children.name: to officially reject a request or suggestion
reject b2
children.definition: reject to use your official authority to formally refuse a request or suggestion: bác bỏ
examples: ▪ judge gifford rejected the defense’s request.
▪ the immigration authorities have rejected his application for refugee status.
▪ it was predicted that the senate would reject the bill by about 60 to 40.
rejection[u] c2
▪ the rejection of the equal rights bill by a small majority

children.name: throw out x
children.definition: throw out if a parliament, a council, or other official political organization throws out a plan or suggestion, they refuse to accept it or make it legal, especially after voting on it: bỏ đi
examples: local councillors threw out proposals for the building of a new stadium.
the house passed the bill, but the senate threw it out.

children.name: turn down b2
children.definition: turn down to refuse to accept a request or to give sb permission to do sth, especially when the request is a reasonable one:bát bỏ
examples: their application to build a new extension has been turned down by the planning authority.
we put in a request for a little extra time for us to finish the project, but the board turned it down.

children.name: refuse b1
children.definition: refuse to officially decide that sb cannot have sth they have asked for, or cannot do sth they want to do:từ chối
examples: refuse an application/request/demand etc
judge eyck refused his request for bail.
over 2,000 applications for political asylum were refused last year.
refuse sb sth
under the law, doctors cannot refuse patients access to their own medical records.
refuse sth to sb
the city is refusing contracts to firms that do not practice an equal opportunities policy.

children.name: say no a1
children.definition: say no/seɪ ˈnəʊ/  to officially refuse to accept a request, suggestion, or bad situation:chính thức bác bỏ
examples: ▪ employees have repeatedly requested child care facilities, but the company has always said no.
nhân viên liên tục yêu cầu những cơ sở vật chất chăm sóc trẻ em nhưng công ty luôn luôn bát bỏ
say no to: bát bỏ
▪ we’re hoping the government will at last say no to low wages and poverty.
chúng tôi hy vọng chính phủ sẽ không bát bỏ về vấn đề lương thấp và đó nghèo

children.name: vote against b1
children.definition: vote against/vote no to refuse to accept a plan, proposal, or new law by voting:chống lại
examples: the majority of union members voted against further industrial action.
homeowners voted against new bonds and higher taxes.
only councilwoman shirley lanion voted no.
vote no on sth
i urge you to vote no on measure a.

children.name: veto x
children.definition: veto to use your position of power to refuse to allow something to happen, especially something that other people, organizations, or countries have agreed:bác bỏ, phủ quyết
examples: ▪ european plans to deregulate air fares were vetoed by spain.
▪ requests to take foster children abroad are often vetoed by the biological parent.
▪ the governor vetoed a bill that would have given some much-needed money to public libraries.
veto[c or u]
as a result of the president’s veto the inner-cities program will not now go ahead.

children.name: give sth the thumbs down x
children.definition: give sth the thumbs downalsoturn thumbs down on sthus  informal to reject a plan or suggestion:phản đối
examples: the commission wisely gave the golf course proposal the thumbs down.
the city council turned thumbs down on marison’s new proposal, citing potential parking problems.

children.name: to state very firmly that you do not agree with sth
reject b2
children.definition: reject/rɪˈdʒekt/ từ chối
examples: ▪ the belief that the children of working mothers suffer is rejected by most child psychologists.
rõ ràng là những đửa trẻ của những người mẹ đi làm đã chịu nhiều đau khổ đã bị bác bỏ bởi các nhà tâm lí trẻ em
▪ the audience is free to accept or reject stone’s interpretation of the facts.
khán giả được tự do chấp nhận hoặc từ chối sự giải thích của stone về nhữn sự thật
reject a suggestion/idea/notion etc that: từ chôi yêu cầu/ ý kiến/ ý niệm
▪ bush rejected suggestions that his tax cuts favored the most wealthy.
bush từ chối những đề nghị về việc thuế của anh ây giảm để ủnng hộ cho người giàu
▪ the author rejected accusations that his novel is blasphemous, but apologized for any offense it had caused.
tác giả đã bác bỏ những cáo buộc rằng tiểu thuyết của anh là phạm thượng nhưng lại xin lỗi về những xuacs phạm đã gây ra

children.name: not accept b1
children.definition: not accept/nɒt əkˈsept/  to not accept a statement, explanation, or decision because you think it is wrong or untrue:không chấp nhận
examples: ▪ our managers claim the new system will increase efficiency but i don’t accept that.
những giám đốc khẳng định rằng hệ thông mới sẽ tăng hiệu quả nhưng tôi không chấp nhận
▪ he said he wouldn’t accept any excuses for missing the deadline.
anh ấy nói rằng anh ấy sẽ không chấp nhận bất kì lí do nào về việc chậm deadline

children.name: dismiss c1
children.definition: dismiss to refuse to acceptsb’sopinions, suggestions, proof etc without even considering it: gạt bỏ, bát bỏ
examples: the judge dismissed most of the police evidence, saying it was clearly fabricated.
one leader dismissed the conference’s findings on the environment as unproven.
dismiss sth out of handdismiss completely without any consideration at all
the argument for higher tariffs cannot be dismissed out of hand.

children.name: to reject ideas, beliefs, or ways of living
reject b2
children.definition: reject to reject ideas, beliefs, or ways of living, especially when you used to accept them in the past:bác bỏ
examples: as an adult, she rejected her catholic upbringing.
vegetarians reject the idea that you must eat meat to get all the nutrients you need.
feminists rejected traditional notions of the role of women in society.
rejection/rɪˈdʒekʃən/ [uncountable noun] sự bác bỏ
rejectionof
sometimes she began to question her outright rejection of her parents’ values.

children.name: turn your back on c2
children.definition: turn your back on to completely change your former beliefs and way of life, especially because you now think that they were wrong:từ chối/ quay lưng lại
examples: i had a sense of relief as i turned my back on the disasters of my first marriage.
some journalists accused him of turning his back on a lot of the party’s major principles.

children.name: scorn x
children.definition: scorn to reject ideas, values, or behaviour because you think they are stupid, wrong, or old-fashioned:khinh miệt
examples: my kids used to scorn my politics as right-wing selfishness.
scornsthassth
many young people scorn polite behaviour as insincere.

children.name: drop out x
children.definition: drop out to refuse to live the way that other people usually live in your society, for example by not working in a job or living in an ordinary house:rút ra khỏi/ bỏ học
examples: while kids in the affluent sixties could afford to drop out, things were very different ten years later.
a group of young people dropped out and set up a commune in the middle of the forest.

children.name: resist b2
children.definition: resistverb cưỡng lại được; kìm nén lại được
examples: [ t ] to stop yourself from doing something that you want to do
i can never resist temptation/chocolate/the urgeto laugh.
[ + -ing verb ]she couldn't resist laughingat him in those clothes.
